title: The Leap of the Rabbit

thumbnail.alt_text: Painting of blue rabbit mid-jump amongst plants and flowers.

description: With its dynamic composition, lush color, and energetic forms, The Leap of the Rabbit exemplifies the unique style Portuguese artist Amadeo de Souza-Cardoso developed while working in Paris from 1906 to 1914. Souza-Cardoso drew on an eclectic mix of sources he encountered in the French capital, including Art Nouveau, the work of Paul Cézanne, and exotic costume designs of Léon Bakst for the Ballets Russes, as well as the native Iberian tilework of his homeland. The Leap of the Rabbit was included in the groundbreaking 1913 International Exposition of Modern Art (better known as the Armory Show), the first major exhibition introducting American audiences to European avant-garde art, where it was purchased by the Chicago collector Arthur Jermone Eddy.
inscriptions: Signed, l.l.: A. de Souza Cardoso/1911

exhibition_history:
New York, International Exhibition of Modern Art, Feb. 17–Mar. 15, 1913, cat. 467; Art Institute of Chicago, Mar. 24–Apr. 16, 1913 (cat. 386, as Rabbit Jump).

The Art Institute of Chicago, Exhibition of Paintings from the Collection of the Late Arthur Jerome Eddy, Sept. 19–Oct. 22, 1922, cat. 17.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Exhibition of the Arthur Jerome Eddy Collection of Modern Paintings and Sculpture, Dec. 22, 1931–Jan. 17, 1932, cat. 15.

The Art Institute of Chicago, A Century of Progress Exhibition of Paintings and Sculpture, June 1–Nov. 1, 1933, cat. 793.

Cincinnati Art Museum, Pictures for Peace: A Retrospective Exhibition Organized from the “The Armory Show” of 1913, Mar. 18–Apr. 16, 1944, cat. 34.

Utica, New York, Munson-Williams-Proctor Institute, 1913 Armory Show—50th Anniversary Exhibition, Feb. 17–Mar. 31, 1963, cat. 467; New York, Armory of the 69th Regiment, Apr. 6–28, 1963.

Paris, Centre national d’art et de culture Georges Pompidou, Musée national d’art moderne, Paris—New York, June 1–Sept. 19, 1977.

Lisbon, Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian, Centenário do Nascimento de Amedeo de Souza Cardoso, 1887–1987, July 20–Oct. 1987. 

Washington, DC, Corcoran Gallery of Art, At the Edge: A Portuguese Futurist, Amadeo de Souza Cardoso, Sept. 11–Nov. 28, 1999, cat. 1; Arts Club of Chicago, Jan. 20–Mar. 17, 2000.

Paris, Grand Palais, Galeries Nationales, Amadeo de Souza-Cardoso, 1887-1918, Apr. 20–July 18, 2016.
provenance_text: The artist; sold through Walter Pach, New York, to Arthur Jerome Eddy (1859-1920), Chicago, Apr. 10, 1913 [letter to the artist, May 2, 1913, Walter Kuhn papers, Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution, copy in curatorial object file; McCarthy 1996; Washington 1999]; by descent to his wife Lucy O. Eddy (1863-1931) and son Jerome O. Eddy (1891-1951), Chicago, 1920; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1931.
